subj-group.subject: Section on Teaching, Learning, and Human Development

title-group.subtitle: The Latinization of U.S. Schools and the Critical Shortage of Latina/o Teachers

fn.p: Jason Irizarry is an assistant professor of multicultural education in the Department of Curriculum and Instruction in the Neag School of Education and Faculty Associate in the Institute for Puerto Rican and Latino Studies at the University of Connecticut. His research focuses on urban teacher recruitment, preparation, and retention with an emphasis on increasing the number of teachers of color, culturally responsive pedagogy, youth participatory action research, and Latino/a students in U.S. schools.

Morgaen L. Donaldson is an assistant professor of educational leadership at the University of Connecticut. Her research focuses on issues pertaining to teacher quality, including teacher retention and evaluation; teachers unions; and principals’ efforts to develop human capital within their schools.

abstract.p: Motivated by shifting demographics and the persistently low academic performance of Latinas/os in U.S. schools, the authors examine factors that influence the recruitment and retention of Latina/o teachers. Applying Latina/o critical race theory and cross-case analysis to data collected from three groups of Latinas/os at distinct points in the teacher pipeline—high school students, undergraduate preservice teachers, and inservice teachers—the authors conclude that the perspectives and experiences of Latinas/os differ significantly from the dominant narrative on teacher recruitment and retention, which is largely defined by White teachers’ career histories. The findings of this study serve as an important race- and culture-conscious counternarrative that can inform efforts to systematically diversify the teaching profession.

body.p: Now numbering more than 50.5 million, the Latina/o1 population in the United States has increased dramatically, growing by more than 350% over the past 30 years (U.S. Census Bureau, 2010). Latinas/os have accounted for half of the overall population growth in the country since the turn of the 21st century, and demographers predict that by 2020 they will number close to 60 million and represent approximately one-fifth of the entire U.S. population (Fry, 2008). Nowhere is the “Latinization” of the United States more evident than in K–12 schools. Nearly one in every four children currently attending school is Latina/o. This group of students is already the plurality in schools in 22 states (Fry & Gonzales, 2008), and substantial increases in Latina/o school enrollment are expected to continue for decades to come (Aud et al., 2010). Demographic projections suggest that by 2050 the Latina/o school-aged population will grow by more than double and Latina/o youth will then constitute the largest group of students in U.S. schools (Fry & Gonzales, 2008).

Substantial population growth among Latinas/os has not been accompanied by sizeable gains in academic achievement. While there are certainly Latina/o students who achieve academic success (Antróp-González, Vélez, & Garrett, 2005; Conchas, 2006), nearly 24% of all Latina/o adults in the United States have less than a ninth-grade education, and almost one in four Latinas/os aged 16 to 24 is either not enrolled in high school or lacks a high school diploma (National Center for Education Statistics, 2008). Approximately half of all Latina/o students fail to complete high school within 4 years, and the majority of those who do are underprepared to meet the rigors of higher education (Swail, Cabrera, & Lee, 2004). Consequently, fewer than 13% of Latinas/os are college graduates (Lopez, 2009). The convergence of these two trends—dramatic population growth among Latinas/os in the United States, also referred to as the “Browning of America,” and a lack of school success for a large segment of this community—presents significant challenges for educators and society at large.

The disheartening academic outcomes for many Latinas/os can be connected, at least in part, to the paucity of Latina/o teachers and other school personnel who may be uniquely equipped to meet the needs of this group (Darder, 1995; Monzó & Rueda, 2001; Ochoa, 2007; Villegas & Clewell, 1998). Of all teachers, 83% are White European Americans while Latinas/os account for only about 7% of teachers (National Center for Education Statistics, 2009).2 Although there are non-Latina/o teachers who effectively teach Latina/o youth, academic, psychological, and social benefits accrue to students of color taught by teachers of color (Dee, 2004; Dillard, 1994; Gay, Dingus, & Jackson, 2003; Villegas & Lucas, 2004). Teachers of color tend to hold higher expectations for minoritized students (Romo & Falbo, 1994; Yeo, 1997), are more likely to value the knowledge and cultural frames of reference students “bring to school” (Irvine, 1989; Monzó & Rueda, 2001), and typically enter the profession with a heightened awareness of the sociopolitical contexts in which students of color are educated (Beaubeouf-LaFontant, 1999; Quiocho & Rios, 2000). They are also more likely to work in “hard to staff” high-minority, high-poverty schools (Ingersoll & May, 2011) and have greater retention rates in those settings (Villegas 2007, 2009).
As such, it is important to understand how to better attract, prepare, support, and retain Latina/o teachers.

There is a relatively small yet important body of literature that focuses on Latina/o teachers. However, to date, these studies have largely focused on discrete portions of the Latina/o teacher pipeline: the education of Latina/o students (Cammarota, 2004; Flores-González, 2002; Rodríguez, 2008; Rolón-Dow, 2005), the experiences of Latina/o preservice teachers (Austin, Willett, Gebhard, & Montes, 2010; Galindo, 1996; Gomez, 2009; Marx, 2000; Téllez, 1999), or the lives of Latina/o inservice teachers (Galindo, 2007; Mayes, Montero, & Cutri, 2004; Monzó & Rueda, 2001; Ochoa, 2007). Research that examines the career paths of Latina/o teachers more comprehensively, connecting the experiences of high school students considering the profession to preservice teachers preparing for the classroom and inservice teachers working within schools, is largely absent. This study speaks to that gap in the literature and aims to contribute to efforts to increase the presence and persistence of Latinas/os in the teaching profession. While this line of inquiry addresses an issue of national import, it is also a deeply personal endeavor. As former teachers in cities with large concentrations of Latina/o students and current faculty members in a School of Education, we are both committed to promoting the success of Latina/o youth and other communities that have been historically underserved by schools. While our experiences working with Latina/o youth and communities give us hope for a brighter future, we remain concerned about the fate of our schools and implications for Latina/o students and others who need to experience Latinas/os in positions of influence, demonstrating care for these children and commitment to their future.

Using critical race theory (CRT) and Latina/o critical race theory (LatCrit) as analytical tools, we employ mixed-methods to demonstrate how the dominant, colorblind narratives regarding teacher recruitment, preparation, and retention promulgated through the research literature fail to adequately speak to the experiences of Latina/o teachers, thus compromising efforts to diversify the profession. This article uses cross-case analysis (Miles & Huberman, 1994; Yin, 2009) to identify salient themes across three sets of data we collected that examine Latinas/os’ progress in to and/or through the teacher pipeline. Two data sets are based on multiyear ethnographic studies, one involving Latina/o high school students considering teaching as a career and the other focused on Latina/o preservice teachers. The third data set is based on a large-scale quantitative study of Latinas/os who entered the profession through Teach For America (TFA), a popular alternative route to certification program with a strong presence in many school districts with high concentrations of Latina/o students and families. We sought to answer the following questions: (a) What competing forces affect the recruitment and retention of Latina/o teachers in the teaching profession? How are Latinas/os pushed and pulled out of the teacher pipeline? and (b) How do the experiences of Latina/o teachers compare to the dominant narratives regarding the professional trajectories of teachers, most of whom are White and middle class?

sec.title: Dominant Narratives Regarding Attracting and Retaining Teachers
sec.p: Either explicitly or implicitly, most of the research on teacher recruitment and retention has focused on White teachers. We establish these dominant narratives as a background for our inquiry and frame our review of the literature around forces that push and pull individuals in to and out of the teaching profession, concepts used by numerous researchers to investigate the entry and persistence of individuals in a particular career (see e.g., Dadley & Edwards, 2007; Danna-Lynch, 2010). We build on and broaden the way in which economists (see e.g., Hoxby & Leigh, 2004) have used these concepts to explain teacher retention in offering the following framing: Forces outside of teaching “push” individuals into teaching or “pull” them out of the profession, while forces within teaching “pull” individuals into the profession or “push” them to leave the classroom.

sec.title: Why do individuals become teachers?
sec.p: On the whole, research suggests that intrinsic motivators play the largest role in drawing teachers in to the profession. Many studies suggest that one of teachers’ primary reasons for entering teaching is to make a difference in students’ lives (see e.g., Farkas, Johnson, Foleno, Duffet, & Foley, 1999). Early studies of teachers’ careers indicated that individuals’ altruism and interest in working with children played major roles in their decision to enter the teaching profession (Goodlad, 1984; Lortie, 1975). Additionally, Lortie (1975) found that a substantial number of teachers reported having liked school and wanting to continue their experience with it, noting, “It is clear . . . that some who attend school become so attached to it that they are loath to leave” (p. 29). Berry’s (1986) interviews with university seniors with high SAT scores led him to conclude that the following perceptions of teaching discourage them from pursuing it: poor working conditions in schools, bureaucratic constraints on teachers’ actions and decisions, and little opportunity for intellectual growth. Financial incentives played a lesser role than these factors.

Indeed, for most teachers, pay is not a primary motivator for choosing this career path, but teachers do expect to receive a wage that enables them to live comfortably (Goodlad, 1984; Lortie, 1975). Loeb and Reininger (2004) draw on several studies in concluding that individuals who are considering teaching assess teachers’ starting salaries relative to alternative occupations in deciding whether or not to teach.

sec.title: Why do teachers leave the profession?
sec.p: Teachers leave teaching for a host of reasons. Broadly, teachers may be pulled out of teaching by greater intrinsic or extrinsic rewards or professional opportunities outside teaching; they may be pushed out of the classroom by poor teaching conditions and scant opportunity for professional growth. Borman and Dowling’s (2008) meta-analysis of 34 quantitative studies led them to conclude that “the odds of attrition are higher among teachers who are female, White, young, and married and who have a child” (p. 396). They further found that the odds that teachers with a science or mathematics undergraduate degree would leave teaching were twice those of teachers with other majors. These teachers may be lured into higher paying jobs in the private sector. They also determined that teachers working in schools with less teacher collaboration or administrative support were more likely to exit. This suggests that the school environment plays a role in teachers’ decisions about whether or not to stay in the profession. Higher salaries were also associated with decreased odds of leaving the profession, especially for more experienced teachers.

Nationwide surveys of teachers echo these push-pull factors. On the most recent (2008–2009) Schools and Staffing Survey (SASS), the top reason teachers selected to explain why they left the profession was “personal life factors,” cited by 42.9% of leavers. In addition, 14.8% cited “other career factors,” 9.8% cited “school factors,” and only 4.0% cited “salary and benefits” (Keigher, 2010).

Within the push-pull factors inherent in teachers’ decisions regarding whether to continue teaching, these results underscore the primacy of personal reasons for entering and leaving teaching and the importance of teachers’ satisfaction with their work. Tschannen-Moran, Woolfolk, and Hoy (1998) found that new teachers who reported lower self-efficacy were more likely to leave teaching. Additional research suggests that working conditions factor into teachers’ decisions regarding whether or not to stay in the profession. Ingersoll and Smith (2003) found that teachers who left teaching because of dissatisfaction cited student discipline problems, lack of support from the school administration, poor student motivation, and lack of teacher influence over schoolwide and classroom decision making as influencing their decision to leave.

On the whole, personal factors, efficacy, and working conditions appear to play a large role in teachers’ decisions to leave teaching. Although it is not the deciding factor in most teachers’ career decisions, pay plays a role in their calculus nonetheless. Several studies have found that while teachers did not offer pay as their motivator for entering the career, they cited it as the second most important factor in their decision to leave teaching (Goodlad, 1984; Johnson, 1990). Observational studies suggest that teachers’ likelihood of leaving the profession decreases when pay is increased (see e.g., Murnane, Singer, Willett, Kemple, & Olsen, 1991).

The majority of research on teacher preparation and retention, including many of the aforementioned studies, rarely places empirical or analytic emphasis on racial differences among teachers. This likely reflects the demographics of both the teaching force and the researchers who examine teachers’ career paths. Because of the disproportionately small percentage of teachers and researchers of color and the pervasiveness of Whiteness within teacher education, research, and broader discourses that shape policy and practice in schools (see e.g., Castagno, 2008; Kirkland, 2010; Sleeter, 2001), race and racial difference are often rendered peripheral if not invisible within much of the research and resultant reform efforts. The grand narratives regarding the trajectories of teachers for the most part ignore racial/ethnic differences among teachers. Given the increasing Latina/o presence in schools and the need to ameliorate Latinas/os’ school experiences and outcomes, the recruitment and retention of Latina/o teachers takes on increased importance. Research regarding how Latinas/os and other people of color are attracted to and retained within the teaching profession is scarce, and additional studies that focus on racial differences and the racialized experiences of teachers of color are necessary to provide an empirical base to support efforts to increase teacher diversity.

The individuals grouped under the umbrella term Latino/a are diverse, and variation exists within and across groups that fall under this overarching identity category. Nevertheless, here we deliberately group Latinas/os together for the explicit purpose of examining factors that influence their presence in and persistence through the pipeline leading into the teaching profession. We acknowledge that some may see this process of “strategic essentialism” (Spivak, 1990) as contributing to an oversimplified and harmful treatment of group identities. However, we believe that temporarily essentializing Latinas/os in this article serves a valuable purpose. Given that few studies have examined Latinas/os’ progress through the teacher pipeline, this article employs the broad (and, admittedly, flawed) category Latina/o to begin to build a knowledge base about this important topic. Moreover, as Latinas/os from all backgrounds are underrepresented in teaching, strategic essentialism serves as a valuable heuristic for research aimed at diversifying the teaching profession and improving the educational experiences and outcomes for Latinas/os and other students who have traditionally been underserved by schools.

sec.title: Critical Race Theory and Latina/o Critical Race Theory
sec.p: Because the role of race/ethnicity in the recruitment, preparation, and retention of teachers has been understudied and undertheorized, we sought a framework that explicitly highlights race/ethnicity and pays special attention to the role of power within racialized systems such as schools. First developed within legal studies, critical race theory and Latina/o critical race theory have gained traction within educational research as scholars have sought to better understand the role of race, racism, and racialization in the educational experiences and outcomes for communities of color (Dixson & Rousseau, 2006; Ladson-Billings & Tate, 1995; Lynn, 1999; Milner, 2008; Solórzano, 1998). CRT challenges hegemonic epistemologies and ideologies such as notions of meritocracy, objectivity, and neutrality and seeks to expose the ways in which racialized power relations shape the experiences of people of color (Chapman, 2007; Sleeter & Delgado Bernal, 2004). While both theoretical frameworks center race in examinations of power, LatCrit aims to extend the focus of analyses to include the intersections between race and other variables, including but not limited to class, gender, language, ethnicity, and immigration status (Delgado & Stefancic, 2001; Huber, 2010; Yosso, 2006a).

While the categories “Latino/a” and Hispanic” are not considered races, the lived experiences of Latinas/os in the context of the United States have most certainly been racialized. For this reason, we use race/ethnicity interchangeably when addressing the experiences of Latinas/os. The impact of race and racialization on the self-identification of Latinas/os is varied and complex, with the meaning Latinas/os ascribe to race shifting over time and highly influenced by their particular geographic context (see e.g., Duany, 2002; Rumbaut, 2011). Creating discursive space for Latinas/os, who can identify themselves using any or multiple racial categories, LatCrit challenges the Black/White binary that often limits considerations of race and racism to two groups. Such an expansion is integral to understanding the multifaceted and nuanced ways that racism impacts the education of Latinas/os and the diverse array of factors that influence the pipeline of Latina/o teachers.

Extending CRT to more adequately address the experiences of Latinas/os, Solórzano and Delgado Bernal (2001) forwarded five themes that undergird a LatCrit framework in education: the centrality of race and racism and intersectionality with other forms of subordination, the challenge to dominant ideology, the commitment to social justice, the centrality of experiential knowledge, and the interdisciplinary perspective. Consistent with a CRT and LatCrit framework in educational research, we sought to amplify the subaltern voices of Latinas/os at various points on their journeys in to and through the teaching profession. This reflects Ladson-Billings and Tate’s (1995) assertion that “the voice of people of color is required for a complete analysis of the educational system. . . . Without authentic voices of people of color it is doubtful that we can say or know anything useful about education in their communities” (p. 58). As the Latina/o population continues to grow and educational indices for this community continue to be discouraging, it is imperative that the perspectives of Latinas/os are solicited and leveraged to transform policy and pedagogy to better meet the needs of Latina/o youth.

Despite the increasing racial and ethnic diversity of U.S. schools, most institutions of education continue to be dominated by Whiteness, an ideology that privileges identity characteristics raced as White over those possessed and enacted by people of color (Kirkland, 2010; Sleeter, 2001). CRT and LatCrit are useful analytical tools for our research, which addresses the underrepresentation of teachers of color, by honoring the experiential knowledge of Latina/o teachers and aspiring teachers and foregrounding their counterstories—race-conscious versions of reality narrated by people of color (Solórzano & Delgado Bernal, 2001; Yosso, 2006a)—to offer a race-based analysis of the factors influencing the presence and persistence of Latino teachers. Remaining mindful of the stark contrast between a profession dominated by Whiteness and the needs of a burgeoning population of students of color, including millions of Latina/o youth, we move beyond solely naming race to critically examine the multifaceted ways racism is manifested in institutional practices and policies that limit opportunities for Latinas/os who may be considering teaching and shape their decisions to persist within the profession.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: For this article, we employed cross-case methods to analyze data that derive from three separate yet interrelated inquiries regarding Latina/o teachers’ experiences in U.S. schools. The first and the second studies, both qualitative, explore the experiences of high school students considering teaching, in the first case, and preservice teachers completing their preparation requirements, in the second. Both samples are drawn from small, postindustrial cities in the Northeast and focus on students or preservice teachers in schools serving predominantly students of color and low-income students. The third study, a quantitative examination of Latina/o TFA teachers’ retention, adds a broader view of the forces that push and pull Latina/o teachers out of the classroom once they enter. Based on a survey of a national sample, this study also speaks to the experiences of Latinas/os in schools with large populations of low-income students and students of color; it is one of the only studies to track Latina/o teachers’ careers in such schools longitudinally.

sec.title: Project FUERTE: Latina/o High School Students Considering Careers in Teaching
sec.p: Study 1 examined the experiences of Latina/o high school students enrolled in an action research course at Rana High School (RHS)3 taught by the first author, who simultaneously conducted a multiyear ethnographic study of those students (for an expanded description of methods, see Irizarry, 2011a). Participants consisted of seven students from RHS, a high school serving approximately 1,000 students in one of a Northeastern state’s lowest performing and most economically depressed districts. They identified themselves as Latina/o, including five Puerto Ricans and two Mexican Americans.

Similar to many U.S. schools, RHS was experiencing a surge in Latina/o population, and the majority of its educators were unprepared to meet these students’ needs. The official annual dropout rate of the school for the year the study began was 4.1%, but a closer look at the data revealed that less than half of all Latina/o students who entered the school as 9th graders were enrolled in the 12th grade 4 years later.

The first author met with the students twice a week for two consecutive academic years, during class, after school, and during school vacations. In all, he spent more than 400 hours with the participants. He constructed field notes after class periods and out-of-school meetings. Student presentations were video recorded and each student was formally interviewed six times over the 2-year period using a standard format for phenomenological interviews (Seidman, 2006). Each interview was transcribed and along with field notes and student work products constitute the data set for this study.

sec.title: Project TEACH: Latina/o Preservice Teachers
sec.p: Study 2 examined the experiences of Latina/o preservice teachers in Project TEACH,4 founded by an institution of higher education, a community-based organization, and an urban school district to “home-grow” Latina/o and African American teachers. For this article, we focus only on Latina/o participants from the final cohort of students in the program.

All participants identified themselves as Puerto Ricans and lived in Hoop City, a midsize Northeastern city where 85% of Latino/a residents are Puerto Rican. When they applied to the program in 1999, all of the participants expressed a desire to teach in the Hoop City School District (HCSD). HCSD serves approximately 26,000 students, almost half of whom are Latinas/os and 75% of whom are eligible for free or reduced fee lunch. On average, 70% of Latina/o students in the district fail to complete high school in 4 years. All of the participants either attended schools or worked as professional staff in HCSD prior to their recruitment into Project TEACH.

The study was aimed at understanding the participants’ journey into the teaching profession with a special emphasis on their experiences as preservice teachers. Data from a variety of sources were collected during the 4 years the students (2001–2005) were enrolled in the program. Notes from meetings with students, field notes crafted after observations, and student application essays served as data sources from when the participants were in college. Three years after the last student graduated, the first author began conducting in-depth phenomenological interviews (Seidman, 2006) with the participants to learn more about their life histories, journeys into teacher education, and experiences while in the program. Each participant was interviewed twice for approximately 90 minutes. All data were transcribed, and these texts served as the primary data sources for Study 2.

sec.title: Teach For America: Latina/o Inservice Teachers
sec.p: Finally, Study 3 was a quantitative study conducted by Donaldson and Johnson that examined turnover among Latinas/os and others who entered teaching through Teach For America. There are compelling critiques of alternative certification in general and TFA’s mission and activities in particular (see e.g., Darling-Hammond, 1994; Lahann & Reagan, 2011; Veltri, 2008, 2010).5 In addition, TFA annually supplies only a small proportion of all new teachers to the nation’s schools. Despite its detractors and limited impact nationwide, TFA’s presence in schools enrolling large numbers of Latinas/os—such as those in Houston, Los Angeles, and the Rio Grande Valley—is considerable. TFA also recruits high-achieving students into its corps; the Latinas/os within TFA may possess a range of skills and knowledge that could help them succeed in the classroom. And alternative certification programs like TFA are increasing, making them particularly important to study. Recent research found that 18.3% of teachers in U.S. schools entered through alternative routes (U.S. Department of Education, 2008). There is some evidence that these programs may be a promising way to recruit teachers of color (Nadler & Peterson, 2009) and place them in urban schools serving large percentages of students of color (Shen, 1998). Given our concerns with the education of Latina/o students and the need to recruit and retain Latina/o teachers in greater numbers, we felt it important that we include data that examine the careers of Latina/o teachers working with high percentages of these students.

With this data set, we investigated the conditional probability (“risk”) that TFA teachers would voluntarily leave their initial school or resign from teaching altogether in every year following their entry into teaching. For an expanded discussion of these methods, see Donaldson and Johnson (2010). The sample for this study is drawn from a census of all teachers enrolled in the 2000, 2001, and 2002 TFA cohorts.6 At the time of the survey, these teachers would have accumulated 4, 5, or 6 years of teaching experience if they had taught continuously. From 3,283 TFA enrollees in these cohorts, 2,029—or 62%—individuals responded to the survey. Of these, 71.4% of respondents are female; 11.54% identified as Black/African American, 6.73% identified as Latina/o/Hispanic, and 77.53% identified as White/Caucasian.

Data for this study were collected by Donaldson and Johnson through an online survey administered in 2007 to the census of teachers.7 The survey requested information on teachers’ individual characteristics (e.g., demographic information, subject matter preparation, and assignment) and, where relevant, on the timing of their first departure from their initial school and/or the teaching profession. Those who had left the profession were asked to explain the motivating factors for their departure, what professions they entered, and how their new occupation compared to teaching on a number of dimensions.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: To analyze data from the three studies, we treated each of them as a case (Patton, 1990; Yin, 2009). According to Patton (1990), case studies are warranted when a researcher wants to develop an in-depth understanding of a phenomenon and “a great deal can be learned from exemplars of the phenomenon in question” (p. 54). We analyzed the data to identify important themes within each case and then across the three cases.

For Studies 1 and 2, interview data were crafted into vignettes (Seidman, 2006). Each vignette was subjected to inductive analysis using the cross-case analysis method (Miles & Huberman, 1994) to generate and analyze themes that emerged across participants. Cases were first analyzed individually and subsequently compared to other cases (Creswell, 1998; Merriam, 1998). To bolster the validity of the findings, frequent member checks (Lincoln & Guba, 1985) were conducted to allow for participant input and verify the accuracy of the interpretations.

For Study 3, the researchers employed discrete-time survival analysis, a method well suited to analyzing longitudinal data. There were two related time-varying outcomes that describe the teacher’s: (a) first voluntary exit from the initial placement school by transfer or resignation from teaching (VEXITSCHL) and (b) first voluntary resignation from the teaching profession (VEXIT) (1 = if event was experienced in this year, given that it had not been experienced in an earlier year; 0 = otherwise). See Appendix C in online journal for variable definitions.

We were interested first in whether Latina/o teachers (1 = if respondent identified as Latina/o, 0 = otherwise) were less likely than Whites to turnover. In our discrete-time hazard models, we controlled for selected covariates, including cohort, gender, whether or not the respondent was related to a teacher, the age at which a teacher entered teaching, his or her college major, and whether he or she was assigned to teach in an urban or rural region in the first year. We included dichotomous variables for all other racial groups except Whites, which was the excluded variable. We used discrete-time survival analysis to determine the probability that Latina/o teachers, compared to White teachers, would voluntarily leave their initial, low-income placement schools by fitting logistic regression models in the teacher-year data set (Willett & Singer, 1991). A typical model is:

where i represents the individual teacher in year j, the α parameters are a set of intercept parameters representing the “baseline” risk that a teacher whose values on all predictors are zero will exit her school for the first time in each year, given that she had remained in the school up to that year. Here, parameter β1 represents the effect being Latina/o on teachers’ risk of exit from their initial placement school. Parameters γ1 and γ2 are vectors of parameters that represent the impacts of time-invariant (Zi) and time-varying (Zij) controls, respectively. We repeated this analysis with voluntary exit (VEXIT) as the outcomes.8 We used chi-square analysis to examine whether or not Latinas/os’ reasons for leaving teaching and new occupations entered differed from those of White teachers who also left teaching.

Bringing the three data sets together, we employed cross-case analysis (Miles & Huberman, 1994; Yin, 2009) to identify cross-cutting themes regarding Latinas/os’ progress through the teacher pipeline. Cross-case analysis is appropriate for this unique compilation of three data sets in that it allows the researchers to reconcile “an individual case’s uniqueness with the need for more general understanding of generic processes that occur across cases” (Miles & Huberman, 1994, p. 173). To facilitate this process, we constructed categorical matrices representing key findings. We then looked across cases to identify key themes, which we then developed in analytic memos. Constructing matrices and then writing memos allowed us to use the constant comparative method (Glaser & Strauss, 1967) to identify and test the robustness of themes across the cases.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: As with all research, this study has limitations. Specifically, the three studies that constitute the data for this analysis differ in key ways. First, each study focused on a different segment of the pipeline from high school student to practicing teacher, which made it impossible for us to compare and contrast themes within a particular segment of the pipeline. Second, the samples are drawn from different geographic areas. While the two qualitative studies’ samples are drawn from similar small Northeastern cities, the TFA sample is national, drawing participants from around the country. Third, only one study, the TFA inquiry, contains an explicit comparison group composed of individuals identifying as “White.” We have sought to address this limitation by drawing on prior research that reported the behaviors and attitudes of White prospective and current teachers. While important to recognize, these limitations do not reduce the importance of this work. To our knowledge, this piece is the first to look at Latinas/os’ experiences across various portions of the teaching pipeline to systematically examine the factors that pull Latinas/os into teaching as well as those that push and pull Latinas/os out of or away from this profession. Motivated by the shifting make-up of our nation’s classrooms, we believe that this study takes an important first step toward understanding the factors that affect the supply of Latina/o teachers.

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: Overall, we found that the perspectives and experiences of Latinas/os differed from the dominant narrative about teacher recruitment, retention, and turnover in notable ways. Our data challenge and disrupt dominant, calcified perceptions of the factors influencing the recruitment and retention of teachers promulgated in the research literature that often eschew racial difference and the pervasiveness of institutional racism in schools and society at large. For example, in contrast to the well-entrenched belief that most teachers enter the profession as a result of positive experiences in schools and caring relationships with teachers, Latinas/os we interviewed cited a desire to combat the negative experiences they had as K–12 students as their primary motivation for entering the profession. They viewed schools as sites of transformation and possibility and overcame numerous obstacles to pursue a teaching career. At the inservice level, Latina/o teachers in our sample were more likely than Whites to stay in the initial, low-income schools where TFA placed them and in the teaching profession, generally speaking. The themes that emerged across our three data sets resonate with previous findings documenting the structural inequality faced by Latina/o K–12 students (Fernández, 2002; Gándara & Contreras, 2009; González, Huerta-Macías, & Tinajero, 2002; Pedraza & Rivera, 2005; Wortham, Murillo, & Hamann, 2002); the experiences of Latinas/os in higher education, generally speaking, and within teacher education programs, more specifically (de la Luz Reyes & Halcón, 1997; Gloria & Kamimura, 2006; Irizarry, 2011b; Sólorzano, Villalpando, & Oseguera, 2005); and the unique skill sets of Latina/o inservice teachers (Galguera, 1998; Haddix, 2010; Monzó & Rueda, 2003; Ochoa, 2007). We now turn to the findings in detail.

sec.title: Return and Resistance: What Pulled Latina/os in to the Teaching Pipeline
sec.p: Across the three data sets, a primary motive for entering teaching appeared to be the desire to give back to one’s community. Latinas/os displayed a forceful commitment to returning to schools like those they had attended to address systematic injustices in their own educational backgrounds. At three points in the teacher pipeline, Latina/o teachers exhibited a strong commitment to teaching in schools serving students of color and low-income students. In these ways, Latina/os in our study differ from the dominant narrative around why individuals enter teaching.

As noted earlier, the teaching profession is composed largely of “good girls” (Galman, 2006) who had positive experiences in schools and entered the profession inspired by teachers with whom they have interacted (Lortie, 1975). The participants in our studies did not conform to that dominant narrative. The majority of the participants in the study of high school students and the study of Latina/o preservice teachers were motivated primarily by a desire to redress negative experiences in schools so that Latinas/os would fare better in the future. Carmen, a high school student, explained:

disp-quote.p: I want to be that teacher that I really never had. Most of the teachers, not all but most of them, like hate Latinos. They just don’t like us. That’s it. They treat us bad and don’t teach us the right way. They don’t think we are going to make it in life, so they like don’t do anything to help us. They ban Spanish. They put us in the lowest classes. They put us ISS [in-school suspension] for stuff they let the White kids get away with. They just don’t want to teach us. That’s why we need more Latino teachers. I want to be that person . . . the one that comes back, believes in Latino kids and works to fix this place.

sec.p: Discussing teaching as a potential career, Carmen and her fellow students in Project FUERTE described a desire to become teachers who could eventually be viewed as role models for Latino students. Their experiences in school were largely negative, dominated by school-sanctioned efforts that discriminated against Latinas/os. They wanted to enter the profession to change the status quo. Their ambitions were rooted in their lived experiences, emerging sense of critical consciousness, and burgeoning commitment to social justice and educational equity. The following interaction among three Project FUERTE students in class highlights the dilemma faced by Latina/o youth who have been systematically marginalized by schools but aspire to become teachers to increase Latinas/os’ educational opportunities:

speech.speaker: Alberto:
speech.p: Why would anyone want to work [as a teacher] here? The teachers here always be hawkin’ [watching] Latinos. There is nothing here for us. They don’t really want us here.

speech.speaker: Taína:
speech.p: Yeah, you right. But maybe it doesn’t always have to be like that. If all of us come back, we can change it. We could like take the school over. (A bunch of students begin to laugh.) Maybe not just one of us but a group of us can come back here to teach and change. We can show them what’s good with Latinos and not just the bad.

speech.speaker: Natasha:
speech.p: If I become a teacher, I am going to be there for my students, especially the Latinos because I know what it is like not to have anyone here [in school] for you. If I go to college, [become] a teacher, and come back here, these teachers are . . . like gonna have to respect me.

speech.speaker: Taína:
speech.p: You know this place is [messed] up. It is gonna be hard, but if we don’t do something the kids coming up are gonna get the same thing ’cause these teachers ain’t gonna change. You know that. We need some new teachers. That’s what I’m talking about.

speech.speaker: Alberto:
speech.p: I feel you on that but do you really want to come here and work with like . . . Mr. [Jones] and Mrs. [Jenkins]? (Everyone starts laughing again.) C’mon now.

sec.p: As they contemplated pursuing teaching as a career and working in the district where they were educated, their conversation moved swiftly back and forth, from an imagined future full of hope and promise where Latina/o students were educated in their best interests to the current sociocultural realities of a school that they experienced as antagonistic and unfriendly. These competing discourses characterized the bulk of their conversations around teaching as a career choice for Latina/o youth. At the same time, they consistently described teaching as a platform from which to challenge the injustices they experienced in schools and transform the institutions they viewed as critical to shaping the opportunities available to Latina/o youth.

The Latina/o preservice teacher candidates in Project TEACH faced a similar dilemma. Recruited from an urban district with the lowest performance and highest dropout/pushout rate in the state, the participants were bombarded by negative messages about their communities from faculty and other students. Like the Project FUERTE students, Latina/o preservice teacher candidates also overcame deleterious, racialized experiences in K–12 schools and saw their future work as teachers as inherently political and potentially transformative. They embarked on their journey to become teachers with a sense of fierce urgency to transform the schools in their community for Latina/o youth and all students. During a group mentoring meeting in her senior year, Jennifer summed up her motivation for pursuing teaching as a career: “I went into teaching because I saw everything that was wrong with [Hoop City] schools. I know it sounds crazy but it is true. I want something different for my daughter and all kids, really.” Instead of internalizing the negative appraisals of their community that dominate the media and some teachers promulgate, the Latina/o preservice teachers in this study leveraged those circumstances to serve as motivation for pursuing careers in teaching. The following comments from Roberto and Gladys reflect the participants’ desire to enter the teaching profession to disrupt and transform an educational system that oppresses many Latina/o students:

disp-quote.p: The Latino community needs help. We are not doing as well as we should be in schools and then obviously can’t get good jobs and things like that. If you really want to make a difference, you should go into teaching. You have the kids for seven, eight hours a day. Think about all of the wonderful things you can do in that time. That is why I wanted to be a teacher. Right now most teachers don’t see that potential. They only see negative things when they look at our kids. I see potential. I see the positive. (Roberto)

sec.p: Similarly, Gladys noted,

disp-quote.p: I had so many bad teachers in school. Thinking back I really can’t remember any really good teachers that stand out. The system ignores Puerto Ricans and other Latinos. I never learned anything about Latinos. Guidance counselors never helped me [apply to college]. Teachers, principals, guidance [staff] don’t do enough to change the system. I made it in spite of the system not because of it. The system needs to change, and I am going to change it.

sec.p: In contrast to the majority of teachers who cite positive experiences in schools as a motivating factor for pursuing teaching as a career, the participants in Project FUERTE and Project TEACH cited negative experiences with teachers and other school personnel as a primary motivator for becoming teachers. They embarked on their professional preparation focused on ameliorating the conditions of schooling for Latina/o youth.

Like Carmen and Gladys, Latina/o TFA teachers displayed a strong commitment to “coming back” to the places where they grew up and giving back to schools like those they had attended. TFA allows corps members to request a placement site from among TFA partner districts. Twice as many Latinas/os as Whites had lived in the specific city/town where TFA placed them (18.95% vs. 10.00%) and 37% of Latinas/os had lived within a 2-hour drive of the place where TFA placed them, compared to 20% of White respondents (p = .002) (see Table 1 for all results for this section. More generally, 68.09% of Latina/os teachers but just 45.88% of White teachers reported having lived in a location as rural or urban as their TFA placement locale (p = .00). Thus, Latina/os in this sample expressed a strong preference to teach in their hometown or in a similar community.

caption.p: Percentage of Respondents in Each Category (n = 1,550).

tr.td: Applied to teaching job in addition to Teach For America (TFA)
Had lived in a location as urban/rural as TFA placement site
Had supervised students similar in race and class to those in TFA placement school
Had lived in specific town/city where TFA placed them
Had lived within a 2-hour drive of where TFA placed them
“Strongly disagreed” that lack of discipline caused them to leave teaching
“Strongly agreed” that salary was a factor in their decision to leave teaching
