My current job’s salary is better than that in teaching
My current job’s “opportunities to make a different in the lives of others” are better than that in teaching
My “sense of personal accomplishment” in my current job are better than that in teaching

sec.p: Latinas/os were also more likely to report prior experience with students and settings that resembled those associated with the low-income urban or rural school in which TFA placed them. Nearly two-thirds (64.21%) of Latinas/os reported that they had supervised students (e.g., teaching, coaching, or leading a youth group) similar in race and class to those in their TFA placement school; in contrast, only 41.41% of Whites reported that they had worked with such students (p = .00).

Overall, Latinas/os in the sample also demonstrated greater interest in entering teaching prior to their initial placement than did their White counterparts. For example, 7.37% of Latinas/os in the sample had majored or minored in education, compared to 5.01% of Whites (p = .05). Latinas/os were nearly twice as likely to have applied for another teaching job when they applied to TFA (11.58% vs. 6.08%, p = .03). These findings suggest that from the outset, Latinas/os in the sample were more committed than their White counterparts to entering teaching whether through Teach For America or another route.

In sum, Latinas/os in Teach For America were more experienced than their White counterparts with both the types of students and the kinds of communities that characterized their TFA teaching placement. Latinas/os’ prior experience with students and communities that were largely low income and of color may have enabled them to cultivate the competencies and capacities to achieve success in their TFA placement more quickly and remain in these placements longer than their White counterparts.

Our data suggest that widely accepted theories utilized to understand how individuals are attracted into the profession are largely insufficient for explaining the professional trajectories of Latina/o teachers. Specifically, Latina/o teachers in these studies demonstrated a particularly strong commitment to teaching and transforming the schools they had attended or those enrolling a similar student population. From a CRT and LatCrit perspective, those characteristics that make Latina/o teachers unique and especially valuable stem from community cultural wealth—“the array of knowledge, skills, abilities, and contacts possessed and utilized by Communities of Color to survive and resist racism and other forms of oppression” (Yosso, 2006b, p. 175)—developed through relationships with the Latina/o communities with which they identify. Moving beyond notions of cultural capital that privilege White, middle- and upper-class cultural frames of reference, knowledge, and meaning making, the paradigm of community cultural wealth posits that characteristics of communities of color are equally, if not more valuable.

In our sample, the Latina/o preservice and inservice teachers demonstrated a fervent commitment to becoming teachers, one that surpassed that of many White teachers. The participants’ willingness and capacity to hold steadfast to their desire to enter the teaching profession in spite of great obstacles, a form of community cultural wealth referred to as aspirational capital (Yosso, 2006a), was distinct. Most notably, the preservice teachers in Projects FUERTE and TEACH had to navigate institutional contexts that were overtly hostile to Latinas/os, harsh spaces shaped by problematic policies and practices that aimed to marginalize Latinas/os and that could have deterred the participants from pursuing and entering the profession if they had not had sufficient aspirational capital. Similarly, the TFA teachers were undeterred in their desire to become teachers, reporting increased interest in the teaching profession and higher rates of community connection. It was the participants’ aspirational capital, we assert, that fueled their desire to become teachers and provided them with the strength to persevere in spite of barriers aimed at impeding their progress.

sec.title: Persistence and Commitment: What Helped Latinas/os Remain in the Teaching Pipeline
sec.p: Across the three data sets, Latina/o teachers displayed particular determination to persist in the pipeline. Despite obstacles, such as the highly racialized practices of academic tracking and high-stakes testing that impeded their academic and professional success, Latina/o preservice teachers in Projects FUERTE and TEACH demonstrated tenacity in pursuing their goals of becoming transformative educators. While they derived strength and support from a variety of sources, all of the individuals in these two programs said that a commitment to their communities and a belief in the potential for teaching to serve as a platform for personal and community uplift attracted them to the profession. In a letter to a future teacher written as a class assignment, Jasmine, a senior in Project FUERTE, cogently articulated her rationale for pursuing teaching:

disp-quote.p: I want to be a teacher, too. I see how teachers can really shape the lives of their students. They can give them hope and give them a chance at life. Right now kids like me, Latino kids, are not getting a good education. I want to change that. I want to come back to my community and help improve it. The best way to improve a community is to improve the schools. No matter what I have to do, how hard I have to work, I am going to make it. I will be a teacher.

sec.p: Likewise, Carmen expressed a commitment to pursuing teaching as a career in an interview at the end of her senior year.

disp-quote.p: School has been tough for me, but I am still going to be an English teacher. My goal is to go to college, become a teacher, and come back and teach here. I want to be the teacher I never really had. It is going to be tough, but that won’t stop me. I’ve been through a lot, and that has made me strong. I won’t quit until I am a teacher.

sec.p: Jasmine and Carmen’s comments reflect determination, which is especially vital as they try to navigate schools that have not served them well. Articulating a commitment is one thing; putting that commitment into action is another. Upon completing high school, Jasmine and Carmen enrolled in a local community college and studied Early Childhood and English, respectively. They both planned to complete their associate’s degree and transfer to a 4-year institution to complete the requirements for teacher licensure.

The preservice teachers in Project TEACH shared a similar resolve to persevere and demonstrated a similar commitment to working in the communities in which they were born and/or raised. They entered the program with the intention of returning to work in the urban school district that most of them had attended. Their desire to “give back” to the communities that nurtured them gave the participants inspiration and strength to endure difficult times during their undergraduate teacher preparation program. Judy faced the most significant obstacles, having passed the teacher licensure exam after her graduation too late, according to the teacher education program’s rules, to have the college endorse her certification. Nevertheless, she persevered. In an interview several years after her graduation, Judy expressed her steadfast commitment to becoming an educator and working in her home community.

disp-quote.p: That policy [to require passing the entire battery of tests before graduation] was BS. I was really hurt and disappointed at the time, but I always knew that no matter what I had to do, I was going to become a teacher in [Hoop City]. That was my life-long goal. Teaching is where I think I can make the most difference for kids, especially Latino kids. [The college] tried to hold me back with the teacher test and making me do the practicum twice. I had to pay to take it again, but I was able to overcome that and succeed. Now I am living my dream. I’m teaching.

sec.p: Without exception, all of the Latina/o preservice teachers articulated and demonstrated a commitment to becoming teachers, ideally in their home communities. Of the seven Project FUERTE students, four are, as of winter 2011, seriously contemplating becoming teachers. Two of the four are undocumented, and without the financial assistance available to U.S. citizens, their access to college is obstructed. Carmen and Jasmine, as noted earlier, have begun the next phase of their preparation, enrolling in college. Four of the five Latina/o members of the final Project TEACH cohort completed undergraduate teacher preparation and embarked on careers in the public school system. Gladys is currently on leave to serve her community in a political appointment. The other three have been teaching for a minimum of 5 years and remain optimistic about their futures in the profession. Although the cohort was relatively small, the retention data for Project TEACH alumni are noteworthy. A consistent thread cutting across the stories of all participants was a commitment to teaching in their home communities and an unwillingness to be deterred.

As foreshadowed by their more robust background with students and communities like those in their teaching placement, Latina/o TFA teachers were more likely than White TFA teachers to remain in their initial, low-income placement schools. Similarly, congruent with their greater initial commitment to teaching, most Latinas/os were also more likely than Whites to remain in teaching altogether. However, Latinas/os with science, technology, or mathematics majors (STEM) were more likely than Whites with those majors to leave the teaching profession.

On the whole, Latinas/os were significantly less likely than White teachers to leave their initial, low-income placement school (see Table 2 for all results with “leave the initial placement school” as the outcome). Controlling for cohort, gender, age, college major, whether one was related to a teacher, and the urbanicity and level of one’s placement school, Latinas/os’ odds of leaving their school in any year were .73 times the odds that Whites would leave (p = .04). Approximately 20% of Latina/o teachers remained in their low-income placement schools longer than 4 years, whereas only 12.8% of their White counterparts behaved similarly. Whether because of their prior experience with similar students or their background in communities like the one in which they are placed by TFA, Latinas/os stayed longer in these low-income schools.

caption.p: Parameter Estimates (Standard Errors) and Goodness-of-Fit Statistics From Selected Discrete-Time Hazard Models in Which the Risk That a Teacher Will Voluntarily Leave Her Initial, Low-Income Placement School Is Predicted by Race, Time, Cohort, Gender, Whether or not One Is Related to a Teacher, Age of Entry, College Major, Placement Urbanicity, and School Level (n = 1,550)

sec.p: Most Latinas/os were also more likely to remain in the teaching profession than their White counterparts (see Table 3 for all results with “leave the profession” as the outcome). Controlling for cohort, gender, age, whether one was related to a teacher, and the urbanicity and level of one’s placement school, Latina/o non-STEM majors were much less likely to leave teaching than all White teachers and Latina/o STEM majors. Latina/o non-STEM majors’ odds of leaving teaching were .70 times those of White non-STEM majors (p = .04). However, Latina/o STEM majors’ odds of leaving were 2.0 times those of White STEM majors (p = .07). And the odds that Latinas/os with STEM majors would exit the profession were more than three times (3.20) those of Latinas/os without these majors (p = .005). For Whites, there was virtually no difference in STEM and non-STEM majors’ probability of leaving the teaching profession. These findings, discussed at greater length in the following, point to the push-pull factors that affect teachers’ willingness to remain in teaching and suggest that the forces that influence high-achieving Latinas/os’ retention may contrast with those that affect their White counterparts.

caption.p: Parameter Estimates (Standard Errors) and Goodness-of-Fit Statistics From Selected Discrete-Time Hazard Models in Which the Risk That a Teacher Will Voluntarily Leave the Teaching Profession Is Predicted by Race, Time, Cohort, Gender, Whether or Not One Is Related to a Teacher, Age of Entry, College Major, Placement Urbanicity, and School Level (n = 1,550)

sec.p: Examined through a CRT and LatCrit lens, the findings strongly support the staying power of Latina/o teachers. The high school students who were contemplating teaching as a career graduated high school and continued their ascent into the profession, a noteworthy feat when one considers that approximately half of their Latina/o counterparts do not complete secondary education and even fewer enroll in institutions of higher education. The undergraduate preservice teachers in the sample remained on course, exerting exceptional effort to successfully navigate college and meet licensure requirements. The data from Latina/o inservice teachers suggest that Latina/o teachers were more likely to remain in schools serving low-income students of color than their White colleagues. We assert that increased retention on a pathway that leads into the profession and within the teaching profession itself reflect the participants’ “resistant capital” (Yosso, 2006a), a form of cultural wealth developed through asserting resistant stances against oppression. In this context, the teachers remained committed to transforming schools. Entering and remaining in the teaching profession represent acts of resistance. As Latina/o students are pathologized in the grand narratives of school reform, Latina/o teachers, by virtue of their presence and the unique skill sets they acquire, challenge and disrupt those majoritarian discourses and replace them with counternarratives of hope and possibility.

sec.title: Barriers and Opportunities: What Pushed or Pulled Latinas/os Out of the Teaching Pipeline
sec.p: At each juncture in the pipeline, potential or actual teachers can be pushed or pulled out of the teaching profession. Formidable barriers depress the numbers of prospective Latina/o teachers who enter the profession. For the high school students in Project FUERTE, the most significant barrier was access to information and courses that would allow them to gain access to college. The racialized practice of tracking, the grouping and placement of students into classes based on their perceived ability levels, resulted in a system of “academic apartheid” (Akom, 2003) in RHS. Latina/o students were largely placed in lower level, less rigorous courses; White students were overrepresented in college preparatory and advanced placement courses. Despite the fact that all of the Project FUERTE students articulated aspirations to attend college, only two of seven 11th graders had taken Algebra 1, a prerequisite for college admission, and none knew what high school courses to take to position themselves as viable candidates for admission into a 4-year college. In fact, at the inception of the study none of the students were aware of their grade point averages nor did they know that this information would be considered in the college admissions process. As the students came to realize the ways in which opportunities in the school were structured to privilege some students, particularly White students in college preparatory courses, and disadvantage Latina/o students who were on a “general” or “fundamentals” track, they expressed frustration with the system.

speech.speaker: Carmen:
speech.p: The Guidance Counselor never has time for us. It is like they figure you are Latino so you are not going to college anyway, and they focus on the White kids. The teachers, guidance, everybody here is like, “Those kids ain’t going to make it” and then they don’t do anything to help us Latinos. They don’t put us in the right classes, and if we want to change our schedule, they don’t have time [to meet with] you. If you want to change into a harder class, you have to get permission from that teacher and then you have to bring your parent. The system is like set up for us to fail.

sec.p: Taína’s experience accessing information for college was similarly fraught with problems and hindered by a lack of communication between counselors and students. All of the students qualified for free or reduced lunch, which entitled them to a fee waiver for the SAT exam, yet most of the participants were unaware of how to access the waiver, how to prepare for the test, or what constituted a “good score.” The following excerpt from a class session during students’ senior year reveals the students’ lack of access to information and experiences that would increase their chances of gaining admission to college.

speech.speaker: Carmen:
speech.p: I didn’t do good on the SAT.

speech.speaker: Taína:
speech.p: I heard that [test] is mad hard. I’m not messing with that.

speech.speaker: Carmen:
speech.p: Unless you are going to community college, you have to take it.

speech.speaker: Taína:
speech.p: For real? How much does it cost?

speech.speaker: Carmen:
speech.p: I don’t know. I got a fee waiver.

speech.speaker: Carmen:
speech.p: I heard if you get free or reduced [lunch] it’s free.

speech.speaker: Taína:
speech.p: For real? Alright. How do you like study for [it]?

speech.speaker: Carmen:
speech.p: You can’t. You just show up and take it.

sec.p: This conversation demonstrates students’ lack of knowledge about a key aspect of the college application process. Without sufficient information about prerequisite courses and entrance examinations, students’ chances of accessing higher education, a necessary precursor to becoming teachers, are severely compromised. Consequently, only two of the seven Project FUERTE students were eligible to apply to 4-year institutions of higher education.

For those Latina/o students who are fortunate enough to successfully navigate high school and access undergraduate programs, there are additional obstacles that can impede them from entering the profession. The experiences of the Project TEACH participants suggest that like their counterparts navigating elementary and secondary schools, there was an anti-Latina/o and anti-“urban” (often used as code to reference Latina/o and Black, economically disadvantaged communities) sentiment that permeated their interactions with faculty, staff, and students and profoundly shaped their experiences at this crucial juncture on their journeys into the profession. Reflecting on his experiences as a preservice teacher 9 years after joining Project TEACH, 5th-year teacher Francisco shared the following:

disp-quote.p: It was hard. You have to deal with a lot of crap sometimes. Most of the professors would talk poorly about [Hoop City]. I grew up here. This is my city. Those kids they talk badly about, all that bad behavior and crime talk and stuff, they are talking about me, my brother, my cousins, my family. They never seemed to understand that when they were criticizing [Hoop City] and [Hoop City Schools] that they were criticizing me personally. That was one of the hardest things for me.

sec.p: Along those same lines, Gladys, a community activist in Hoop City who entered the teacher preparation program after working as a paraprofessional, focused her critique of teacher preparation on the climate created by insensitive faculty, staff and students.

disp-quote.p: [The faculty] would always say things like, “Don’t walk to your car alone when you leave the school in [Hoop City].” They would say, “Make sure you lock your car.” What are they telling these White teachers? To be scared of [Hoop City] and the people who live there.

sec.p: All participants described frequent instances of racial discrimination and cultural insensitivity within their preservice teacher education program. They spoke poignantly about how these overt acts of discrimination and more subtle racial microagressions, insults, often subconscious or automatic, aimed at people of color (Solórzano, Ceja, & Yosso, 2000) prompted them to contemplate leaving the program and abandoning their pursuit of the teaching profession.

Beyond problematic interactions with faculty and other students, there were also structural impediments that hindered Latina/o teacher candidates in their pursuit of an undergraduate degree and educator licensure. Most notably, the creation and implementation of a state teacher licensure examination presented a formidable barrier that threatened the progress of Latina/o teacher candidates. In an attempt to raise standards for teachers and pressure institutions of higher education to take more responsibility for ensuring teacher quality, the state mandated that 80% of preparation program participants pass the tests. Failure to meet the new benchmark would result in the college losing state accreditation. To protect against this, the Project TEACH institution, like many others in the state, made passing the state exam a prerequisite for official admission into the program even though it was designed to be an exit exam measuring teachers’ knowledge. Teacher education students who did not pass the tests were not allowed to officially enroll in certain upper-level courses required for licensure. Like other standardized measures of achievement, including the ACT and SAT, Latina/o and African Americans have consistently received lower scores on teacher tests (Flippo & Riccards, 2000; Smith, 1987; Valencia, 1991). The Latina/o preservice teachers in Project TEACH struggled to pass the exam and voiced their displeasure with their institution’s complicity in using a test known to yield disproportionately lower scores for Latina/os as a gatekeeping mechanism, potentially blocking them from completing their programs and earning a teaching credential. Comments from Roberto and Jennifer echo the sentiment of the group. Reflecting on the willingness of the institution to blindly engage in a potentially discriminatory practice that might limit diversity in their program and the profession at large, Roberto noted:

disp-quote.p: They [the teacher education program and institution of higher education] know that the test is unfair, but they use it anyway. That tells me that they don’t care about us . . . about [producing] Latino teachers. This is one more thing to block us from getting into schools [as teachers] to help our kids.

sec.p: Jennifer expressed similar frustration and anger regarding how the policy temporarily derailed and delayed her entry into the teaching profession:

disp-quote.p: Because I didn’t pass [one of the tests], they won’t count my practicum, even though I did all the work. Even if I pass the test after I graduate, they won’t [endorse] my certification. I will have to pay more and do the practicum again. I only missed [achieving a passing score] by 3 points. That’s completely wrong.

sec.p: Roberto, Jennifer, and all but one of the other Project TEACH students passed all of the tests required for certification. Jennifer demonstrated exceptional perseverance and continued to take the test, passing shortly after her graduation. As noted earlier, to obtain licensure and achieve her goal of becoming a teacher, she re-enrolled in the institution of higher education, completed an additional practicum experience and student teaching seminar, and is now a successful elementary teacher. If Latinas/os can successfully navigate the often hostile environments of K–12 schools and preservice teacher education programs, they are then faced with working in a profession that has not always supported them.

Approximately half of all teachers leave the profession within 5 years (Ingersoll, 2003), and the rates of departure are higher in schools serving larger percentages of students of color and students from lower socioeconomic strata (Ingersoll, 2001). Latina/o inservice teachers in our study who left teaching tended to be pulled out of teaching by opportunities in other fields more than pushed out by poor working conditions; they were less likely to cite school factors and more likely to cite external opportunities as influencing their decision to leave (see Table 1 for all reports presented in this section). In fact, 56.90% of Latinas/os compared with 46.16% of Whites disagreed or strongly disagreed with the notion that a lack of discipline in their placement schools pushed them to leave teaching (p = .08). In addition, 24.13% of Latina/o teachers but just 13.87% of Whites agreed or strongly agreed that salary was a factor in their decision to leave teaching (p = .006). Thus, Latinas/os seemed not to be pushed out of teaching by the difficult working conditions but pulled out by more lucrative offers in other fields. This latter finding likely speaks to the relatively high likelihood that Latina/o STEM majors would leave teaching.

Consistent with this theory, Latina/o leavers held different occupations than White leavers. Latina/o leavers were more likely than White leavers to work in medicine, engineering or architecture, or an education nonprofit. Latina/o leavers were more than three times as likely as White leavers to work in medicine (5.08% vs. 1.68%, p = .06) and more than five times as likely as Whites to work in engineering or architecture (5.08% vs. .99%, p = .005). Almost twice the proportion of Latina/o leavers worked in educational nonprofits, compared to White leavers: 20.34% versus 11.53% (p = .04). Although not statistically significant, Latinas/os who left teaching were also more likely to have entered business or become principals.

When they compared their current jobs to teaching on a number of different dimensions, again, Latinas/os’ responses were different from those of their White counterparts who also left teaching. Latinas/os were more likely than Whites to say that their current job’s salary was better than that in teaching (64.81% vs. 49.06%, p = .08). They were also more likely than Whites to say that the “opportunities to make a difference in the lives of others” in their current job were better than those in teaching (25.93% vs. 12.60%, p = .01). Lastly, they were more likely than Whites to say that their “sense of personal accomplishment” was greater in their current job than it was in teaching (37.04% vs. 24.31%, p = .05). It appears that high-achieving Latinas/os in this sample had found professions that were more financially lucrative than teaching but also allowed them more opportunities to give back to society while also feeling professionally fulfilled. The findings suggest that medicine, engineering and architecture, and the nonprofit sector are successfully recruiting some high-achieving Latinas/os out of teaching.

Applying CRT and LatCrit frameworks to these data sets, we argue that through their experiences successfully navigating high school and undergraduate programs, the students developed and refined their “navigational capital” (Yosso, 2006a). That is, Latina/o teachers were particularly skilled in navigating complex, often hostile social institutions. Although not a focus here because of space constraints, the participants also demonstrated additional forms of cultural wealth including linguistic capital, stemming from their ability to speak multiple languages and context-specific language variations, and familial capital garnered through connections to family, broadly defined, and manifested in cultural intuition and other tools for meaning making developed through extended time spent in communities of color. The combination of their content knowledge and cultural wealth makes these teachers valuable not only to schools but also to other professions. Other professions may place more value on these skills than schools yet still offer platforms for Latina/o educators to fulfill their commitments to their communities, often in settings that offer employees more professionalism, responsibility, support, and respect than do schools or public education.

sec.title: Discussion and Implications
sec.p: Although all teachers, regardless of race and ethnicity, have a role to play in better serving Latina/o students, our schools must improve their efforts to recruit and support Latina/o teachers. Here, we have examined the experiences and perspectives of Latina/o practicing and aspiring teachers. In contrast to teacher pipeline narratives that overlook or render silent the perspectives of teachers of color, the Latina/o teachers and aspiring in this study offer an important race-conscious counternarrative that challenges and destabilizes the popular understandings prevalent in the research literature and dominant discourse about how teachers are attracted and retained in the teaching profession.

Using cross-case methods to analyze data from three interrelated studies of Latina/o aspiring or practicing teachers in schools composed largely of students of color and low-income students, we found that Latina/o participants displayed distinct motivations for aspiring to enter or actually entering the teaching profession. A desire to “come back” to schools they attended or similar settings appeared to pull these individuals into the teaching career. Numerous participants in the qualitative studies expressed this opinion, which has surfaced in prior work (Téllez, 1999). In the TFA study, Latinas/os were significantly more likely than Whites to teach in the locale where they had grown up and to have had more general prior experience with the kinds of communities and types of students that characterized their teaching placement. At the same time, like some previous studies (see e.g., Galindo, 1996, 2007; Telléz, 1999), participants in these studies responded directly to their own largely negative experience as students, voicing a strong desire to transform schools, making them more positive learning environments for Latina/o students like themselves.

We further found that the factors that retained Latina/o participants in either the pipeline or the classroom were unique. Latinas/os in our data sets persisted because of an “I won’t quit” attitude, in the words of one participant, that enabled them to overcome a host of obstacles to their pursuit of a teaching career and their continuation once in the classroom. Perhaps because of this attitude, Latina/o TFA teachers were significantly more likely than White teachers to remain in their low-income school placement and the majority of Latina/os in the sample were also more likely than White teachers to remain in the profession overall. The exception to this pattern was Latina/o STEM majors, who were more likely than any other group to leave teaching. We do not believe this reflects the trite adage: “Those who can’t, teach.” TFA teachers, regardless of major, graduate from selective universities and typically have access to a range of career options. We believe this finding speaks more to the high demand for Latina/o STEM majors in other professions, such as medicine, that offer individuals a chance to serve their community but also provide them with salaries and status that are substantially higher than is typical in K–12 teaching positions. The Latinas/os who enter teaching through TFA and choose to stay in teaching are clearly doing so because they are committed to the work, not because they lack other career options.

Lastly, we found that Latinas/os in our data sets described unique factors that pushed or pulled them out of the teaching pipeline or profession itself. For Latinas/os considering or preparing for teaching in our samples, systemic barriers such as tracking and certification tests proved especially strong obstacles to their progress through the teaching pipeline. Moreover, access to important information about gaining access to the teaching profession—why to take Algebra I, when to take the SAT, how to pay for it— proved another critical obstacle that pushed the Latina/o high school students away from pursuing teaching as a career. Similarly, Latina/o TFA teachers were pushed or pulled out of teaching by unique factors. Latina/o teachers were almost twice as likely as Whites to agree or strongly agree that salary was a major factor in their decision to leave teaching. Moreover, Latinas/os who left teaching were more than three times as likely to enter medicine and more than five times as likely to become engineers than were Whites. Overall, the factors that pulled and pushed Latinas/os out of the teaching pipeline differed substantially from those that, according to the literature, deter Whites from continuing on this path.

The powerful counternarratives shared here—perspectives from Latina/o preservice and inservice teachers that challenge majoritarian stories regarding the professional trajectories of teachers—suggest that race does in fact matter in the recruitment, preparation, and retention of teachers and, as such, should merit increased attention. CRT and LatCrit also challenge colorblind and “cultureblind” narratives about educational attainment that lay claim to objectivity and neutrality and are rooted in uncritical notions of meritocracy. When applied to our data, these theoretical lenses help illuminate the role racialized forms of structural inequality play in shaping the career aspirations of current and future teachers. The educational conditions encountered by the participants in their schooling experiences and in their initial teaching placements are specific to schools serving large percentages of students of color and students from lower socioeconomic strata. They serve to suppress some and privilege others based on their race/ethnicity, socioeconomic status, and other factors. Central to dismantling the social reproductive function of schools that stifles the supply of Latina/o teachers is increasing the presence of teachers of color working in these settings. While racial matching has been found to result in academic benefits for students of color (Dee, 2004; Zirkel, 2002), including Latinas/os, our data suggest that the positive impact of Latina/o teachers on Latina/o students may not result solely from teachers identifying nominally as Latina/o. Building on and extending the concept of community cultural wealth, these findings suggest that Latina/o teachers are more connected to the communities in which they teach than White teachers and often bring emic perspectives regarding how to successfully navigate schooling, particularly in difficult contexts, that make them an especially valuable resource. When applied to the study of the recruitment and retention of teachers, critical race theory and Latina/o critical race theory expose the “whitewashing” of research related to teacher development and the calcification of dominant narratives that minimize or completely fail to recognize racial/ethnic differences among teachers. By shifting attention to the educational and professional trajectories of Latina/o teachers, with special attention given to how they are shaped by issues of power and privilege, CRT and LatCrit also highlight the value Latina/o teachers add to the profession and their potential for improving the quality of education for Latina/o and other youth.

The participants’ connections to Latina/o communities helped them persevere and successfully navigate schools and institutions of higher education that they described as hostile toward Latinas/os. The teachers and aspiring teachers in our study developed and leveraged valuable information networks within their communities to inform their decisions to enter the teaching profession, fuel their desire to remain working in these settings, and influence the types of teachers they aspire to be. The knowledge and cultural frames of reference possessed by Latina/o teachers and aspiring teachers—those “barrio-based epistemologies and ontologies” (Irizarry & Raible, 2011) developed through sustained immersion in and commitment to Latina/o communities—are not included as part of the traditional teacher preparation curriculum or most district professional development programs, nor are they measured on licensure exams or considered in the evaluation of teachers. It is their familiarity with the often overlooked yet extremely valuable information networks present in Latina/o communities and active participation in these information networks that position the Latina/o teachers in this study as uniquely qualified for the teaching profession. If school districts, schools of education, and other constituents are serious about improving the educational quality and academic outcomes of Latina/o youth, the largest, fastest growing, and one of the lowest performing groups of minoritized students in U.S. schools, creating pathways for Latinas/os into the teaching profession is imperative.

We acknowledge that there are limitations to our inquiry, including our focus on three distinct groups of participants at different points in their professional development rather than following one group longitudinally from high school, through college, and into the classrooms as teachers. Nevertheless, we believe the “pipeline” perspective offered here and the important findings that emerged across the three cases are noteworthy. Typically research on recruitment and retention focuses on inservice teachers, exploring factors that influence teachers’ decisions to remain or leave the profession (Borman & Dowling, 2008; Lortie, 1975). The research literature regarding preservice teachers most often includes only students engaged in higher education or alternative route to licensure programs. By expanding our examination to include high school students in a period critical to their access to the teaching profession, our study provokes the extension and reconceptualization of the teacher pipeline metaphor and offers valuable information for those invested in improving the experiences and outcomes for Latina/o youth and their communities.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: In addition to offering alternative, race-conscious perspectives on social phenomena, analyses informed by CRT and LatCrit theories should be leveraged to address racial inequality and transform social institutions such as K–12 schools and institutions of higher education (Lynn, 1999; Rolón-Dow, 2005; Sólorzano et al., 2005). Building on theory to drive practice, the practical implications emerging from the application of CRT and LatCrit to our analysis can contribute to more race-conscious approaches to improving the educational experiences and outcomes for Latina/o and other youth of color by informing efforts to diversify the teaching profession.

For many Latinas/os, the low-quality education they receive as students restricts their professional options. Latinas/os who have dropped out or been pushed out of high school, those who have successfully navigated high school but were not prepared with the skills necessary to embark on higher education, and those who enter college but fail to complete their studies—totaling more than 85% of the entire Latina/o population—are virtually shut out from pursuing careers in teaching. The miseducation of Latina/o youth initiates an insidious cycle that results in the underrepresentation of this community in teaching and other knowledge-based professions. Because of the diminished population of Latina/o teachers, schools are unable to attract sufficient numbers of teachers who speak students’ languages, are connected to their communities, and have the potential to increase the academic achievement of Latina/o youth. Consequently, the majority of Latina/o students continue to languish in classrooms where their histories are omitted from the curriculum, the sociocultural realities of their lives are largely ignored, and their futures are severely compromised, virtually ensuring that the supply of Latina/o teachers will remain depleted. In order to develop a more diverse teaching force, schools need to be transformed into institutions that foster the intellectual and personal growth of youth of color.

Teacher education programs can also play a major role in addressing the critical shortage of Latina/o teachers by working to attract diverse candidates into the profession and more effectively preparing all teachers to work with the students who need them most. Findings from this study speak to the need for teacher education programs to conduct systematic outreach efforts aimed at attracting Latinas/os to teaching as a profession and providing support for them along the way. Transforming the racial/ethnic texture of the teaching force is a long-term endeavor, one that will take years to realize. In the interim, teacher preparation programs can do more to better prepare all teachers to work effectively across lines of cultural and linguistic difference. Producing more culturally responsive teachers can lead to improved instruction and important learning gains for Latina/o youth, thus increasing their ability and qualifications to pursue higher education, a prerequisite for entering the teaching profession. Simultaneously, more attention needs to be given to creating an environment within teacher education programs that is more supportive of Latina/o teacher candidates.

Our study also provides important insights for schools seeking to recruit and retain Latina/o teachers. In addition to the changes needed in PK–12 schools to improve learning opportunities for Latina/o students, schools also need to be transformed into more rewarding places in which to work so as to attract and retain high-achieving Latinas/os. With an increasing array of professional options available to highly educated Latinas/os, the teaching profession is competing with other, sometimes more intrinsically and extrinsically rewarding professions that may place relatively greater value on the funds of knowledge Latinas/os bring with them to their work. To attract Latinas/os with strong academic backgrounds, schools need to become places that are conducive to the personal and professional growth of teachers as well as students.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite increased attention to closing gaps in opportunity and achievement between White students and students of color, one of the largest challenges for schools remains improving the education of students from communities who have been subordinated because of their race/ethnicity, class, and language. Schools of education are confronted with the daunting task of preparing a population of predominantly White, monolingual teachers to meet the needs of a burgeoning population of Latina/o youth and other students from multilingual communities. Latina/o teachers can be central to these efforts yet remain in short supply. Challenging the dominant narratives that permeate the discourse on teaching and inserting the heretofore silenced perspectives of Latinas/os represents an important point of departure for transforming the ways we think about how to attract candidates of diverse backgrounds into the teaching profession.

The Latinization of the United States, evidenced through population growth and the desire of Latinas/os to preserve and assert their identities in the face of significant pressures to assimilate, requires revised notions of national identity and nationhood. If youth are indeed the future of the country, and that future is becoming “browner” with each passing year, the education of Latina/o youth is a matter of national importance. The projected expansion of the Latina/o population and the persistent disheartening academic outcomes for this community, contrasted with the lack of racial/ethnic diversity of the teaching force, calls attention to the need for increased investments in the education of Latina/o youth. In contrast to educational policies that negatively target Latinas/os, such as the proposed elimination of ethnic studies in Arizona and the eradication of bilingual education in several states with large concentrations of Latina/o students, the data suggest that creating policies aimed at increasing opportunities for Latinas/os to become teachers is a worthwhile endeavor that could positively shape the educational, personal, and professional trajectories of future generations. The burgeoning population of Latinas/os in the United States offers a unique opportunity to transform the racial/ethnic composition of the teaching force, attracting and preparing teachers to “Teach for América,” the accented Spanish phraseology reflecting a new race- and culture-conscious discourse that underscores the need for a teaching force that can more effectively work within the context of the Latinization of U.S. schools. The assets Latina/o teachers bring with them into the profession suggest that school districts and teacher education programs must pursue teacher diversity with renewed enthusiasm and vigor.

fn.p: We use the term Latina/o throughout the piece to remain consistent with the terminology commonly used in the research literature and to be more inclusive of gender diversity among Latinas/os. The majority of our participants were female, and we are therefore deliberately using the feminine form first. However, we acknowledge that the term is also problematic in that it reinforces an arbitrary binary, limiting the social construction of gender to only two genders. As the scholarship regarding the experiences of Latinas/os continues to evolve, we must remain mindful of how terminology can simultaneously affirm the identities of some while suppressing those of others.

Latina/o representation in the teaching force is growing. In 2008, 7.9% of elementary and 7.0% of secondary teachers were Latina/o, compared to 6.1% and 5.1%, respectively, in 2000 (Aud et al., 2010). However, this increase was far outpaced by the growth in Latina/o student population, which rose from 16% to 22% of overall student enrollment during the same time period.
All proper names in this manuscript are pseudonyms.
See Appendix B in the online journal for a complete list and brief description of the Project TEACH participants.

Compelling critiques of Teach For American (TFA) exist. For example, Darling-Hammond (1994), Veltri (2008, 2010), and others have asserted that TFA corps members, largely White and upper middle class, benefit more from TFA than do the low-income students of color whom they teach. Lahann and Reagan (2011) problematize TFA’s “progressive neoliberal” ideology and practices. Heilig and Jez (2010) review the research to date on TFA and raise questions about TFA members’ impact on student achievement.

We included three cohorts in data analyses in order to improve statistical power. A priori power analysis suggested that the resulting sample size should provide sufficient statistical power to detect small effects (Cohen, 1977).

For a full description of the instrument see Donaldson and Johnson (2010). Donaldson and Johnson created the instrument by drawing on the School and Staffing Survey, earlier questionnaires on new teacher retention, and literature on survey question design (Dillman, 1978) and reducing recall error (Sudman & Bradburn, 1982). Donaldson and Johnson piloted it with 30 TFA teachers from cohorts who entered the profession immediately prior to 2000 or after 2002 and tested survey questions and the online process with 812 teachers in another program who were demographically similar to TFA teachers.

In fitting models, we made judgments about whether or not to retain predictors using post hoc general linear hypothesis (GLH) tests based on differences in the −2 log likelihood goodness-of-fit statistics, comparing differences to a χ2 distribution with the appropriate degrees of freedom. We also evaluated their impact in specific years based on post hoc general linear hypotheses tests that determined whether individuals with less complex assignments (i.e., a single grade or subject or an in-field assignment) had a significantly higher risk of experiencing the outcome in a given year than those with more complex assignments in the time period specified.
